title: rachael-hamilton-borders-msp-given-new-party-position
story: A CONSERVATIVE MSP for the Borders has been given a change of role within her party.Rachael Hamilton is now the shadow cabinet secretary for social security and older people.It comes in a reshuffle co-ordinated by Douglas Ross MP, the new leader of the Scottish Conservatives.Mrs Hamilton ndash the Holyrood representative for Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire ndash said she is ldquodelighted about the role change.Mrs Hamilton was first promoted to the shadow cabinet in February when she was unveiled as the shadow cabinet secretary for rural affairs and tourism.

title: huge-asset-borders-closed
story: THE Girl Guide movement in Scotland has been left ldquoheartbroken after it was announced this week that its Borders-based activity centre would shut for good.The closure of Netherurd House near Blyth Bridge is said to be due to financial dficulty, with the impact of the coronavirus pandemic being the final nail in the coffin.Staff will be made redundant, with the exception of the groundskeeper who will be retained until the estate is sold.Margot Swanston, who has visited Netherurd for  years as a guide and leader, described herself as ldquodevastated.The stunning Georgian mansion and its extensive grounds have served thousands of guides and brownies for more than  years.After finances plummeted five years ago, a review was carried out which resulted in signicant investment to improve facilities and make it more attractive for users.There was an initial increase in bookings, but over the last three years numbers dropped, resulting in fewer users and financial woes.Girlguiding Scotlandrsquos chief commissioner Moira McKenna said: ldquoIn the past, we regularly used to fill the house with adults for county and other training weekends, but this has been declining for at least the last decade.ldquoFewer counties book for training, more of them come for only one night and the numbers from each county are lower than in previous times.ldquoThere is now much more training available online and this has increased dramatically this year with COVID-.ldquoEven before the pandemic came along, Girlguiding was planning to set up a digital hub to provide training online, and whilst we know the value of being together, volunteers across Scotland are finding the online or local training options more convenient in terms of both time and money.ldquoWe had hoped to build external business for mid-week, especially schools, but we were unable to build a wide enough business base to rely on this.ldquoEach year we have tried other avenues including holidays for Trefoil groups, retreats for local churches, private family gatherings and occasional weddings, but overall we could not generate enough routine business to help us improve the finances.ldquoThis was the situation before we were forced to close Netherurd in March due to COVID-, and since then the centre has had no income.A spokesperson for Netherurd House added: ldquoWe want to take this opportunity to say a huge thank you to all the staff and volunteers who have made Netherurd a place of adventure and provided ever-lasting memories for so many girls and young people.ldquoThis is a signicant loss to Girlguiding Scotland and we know many will be upset by this news.ldquoOur priority remains our members and wersquore committed to ensuring that girls and young women can keep having adventure and benefit from all that the outdoors has to offer.Former visitors to Netherurd House took to social media calling the closure a ldquosad day for Girlguiding Scotland.,params: .pushOne woman wrote: ldquoDreadful news. Broken-hearted doesnrsquot begin to describe the way Irsquom feeling. Netherurd has always been a home away from home to me.Joyce Sundstrem added: ldquoSuch sad news, an integral part of our Guiding over the years. Happy memories of training weekends and pack holidays there.ldquoItrsquos a shame to think the future rainbows, brownies and guides wonrsquot have the same chance to visit as we had.Many leaders and former users have described the news as a ldquodevastating tragedy for guiding and have even called for a rescue mission.Ms Swanston, the guidesrsquo assistant commissioner for Peebles, said: ldquoWe all hope it can be saved. I, as a guider, am devastated."I was  years old on my first guide camp and since then have stayed in the old Brownie house, the new Brownie house, and the big house itself.ldquoIt is not only a huge asset to Peeblesshire and the Borders, but to the whole of Scotland as it is the only residential venue owned by Girlguiding in Scotland.Ms Swanston and her family have strong ties in the Guiding movement and she says they have many happy memories of their time spent at Netherurd House.One cherished memory was formed only last October, when Ms Swanston renewed her Guide Promise after  years in Guiding.She added: ldquoMy granddaughter Megan took her Guide Promise for the first time and we were honoured by being enrolled by the Scottish Chief Guide.

title: peebles-family-walking-500-miles
story: A PEEBLES family are making the Proclaimersrsquo smash hit a reality by walking  miles.The McGrath clan are lsquogonna bersquo clocking up the miles this month for a brave girl who was born with a potentially fatal condition.Sandra McGrath said: ldquoCollectively we aim to walk  miles between st and th August and are well on track to smash that target.ldquoWe hope to raise pound, and, again, are already well up towards that total.The money will go towards the charity DEBRA, which funds research trying to find a cure for Epidermolysis Bullosa . The condition causes internal and external blistering.Sandra and her husband Mike were due to take part in the Great Wilderness Challenge in Wester Ross, alongside their daughter Sarah Keen and son Allan.Although the pandemic put the brakes on their plans, the family were determined to help DEBRA.The charity looks after -year-old Isla Grist, who lives near Inverness.Born at home, the paramedics who delivered Isla immediately rushed her to hospital where, for the first six months of her le, her parents Rachael and Andy carried her around on a pillow as the slightest knock or rub could tear her skin.Isla has had a painful le with endless visits to Great Ormond Street Hospital for treatments and operations.Every step, knock, or bumpcan cause permanent damage and her body is completely bandaged with thrice-weekly changes.Islarsquos plight is close to the McGrath familyrsquos heart, and for the last  years Mike and Sandra have been taking part in the Great Wilderness Challenge.Together with their extended family and friends, they raised pound, for the charity last year.Due to the events cancellation this year, they decided to fundraise with their own personal family challenge.Sandra said: ldquoWersquove done our walking running in the forests and hills around Peebles.ldquoAlso our son Allan McGrath, his we Rhona, and -year-old twins, Duncan and Isla, and -year-old Kirsty have taken part.ldquoThey did some walking around Edinburgh and are now continuing to complete their mileage from our holiday cottage in Gairloch, Wester Ross.EB affects every part of Islarsquos le and the family have had to adapt to a dferent kind of normal, like two trampolines ndash one for Isla and one for her sister Emily.And simply running around with friends is out of the question as it poses a danger to Isla.DEBRA is funding pioneering research into effective treatments and a cure for the condition.The McGrath family have proved they will walk  miles and more, just to be the ones to help Isla live the pain-free le she so desperately hopes for.

title: 10-mistakes-making-fridge
story: Recommendations are independently chosen by Reviewedrsquos editors. Purchases you make through our links may earn us a commission.There are right and wrong ways to store your food. For example, some food must be refrigerated while other types need to be kept at room temperature.Some cooking oils are fine on the countertop, and others should be stored in the fridge.Even some of your expired foods arenrsquot really expired, and you might be using the wrong containers. With food storage at a premium, you dont want to let anything go to waste.Wersquove done the legwork to figure out the right ways to store your food so that it tastes best and lasts the longest.Here are the answers to ten common kitchen storage mistakes.. Youre throwing out your lsquoexpiredrsquo foodCertain expiration dates have less to do with safety than they do quality. Credit: Getty   FangXiaNuoItrsquos important to know the dference between food that has passed the lsquoBest Beforersquo date and food that has passed the lsquoUse byrsquo date. You should never eat food that has passed its lsquoUse byrsquo date, but lsquoBest Beforersquo dates often reflect quality control, not safety or nutritional value. In determiningthe food that has passed the lsquoBest Beforersquo is safe to eat read up on Food Standards Agency guidelines, use your eyes and nose, and follow your gut.Smell:If it smells fine and it was stored properly, its likely okay to eat.Sight:Donrsquot let your eyes fool you when it comes to fresh food like produce. Bumps or bruises donrsquot mean something is ruined.Dont can the cans:Canned goods can last for decades. Even a can thats started to rust should still be okay, as long as it isnt bulging and the seal is intact.Check the packaging, use your senses, cook food thoroughly, and donrsquot let the perfect become the enemy of the good. A proper understanding of expirationdates could drastically cut down on food wastemdashnot to mention wasted money out of your pocket.. Youre using plastic wrap to save your leftoversBees Wrap can be used to store anything from biscuits to sandwiches. But not soup... yet. Credit: Bees WrapIf yoursquore sick of throwing away disposable food wrap but still want to keep food fresh, Beersquos Wrapmight be your answer. This reusable food wrap is made from beeswax and fabric.Itrsquos designed so you can build a sandwich on top of it in your kitchen, then unwrap it to use as a placemat. Beersquos Wrap is also ideal for food storage. An avid home baker, creator Sarah Kaeck said itrsquoll help keep bread crusty and soft. Itrsquos also great for wrapping cheese, half of an avocado, half of a lemon, covering jars and bowls .Afterwards, just wash it with cold water , hang-dry, and use it again. It should last about a yearyou use it a few times a week.. Youre refrigerating these foodsmdashand you shouldnt beNot everything goes in your fridge. Credit: Getty   SolStockSome foods are actively made worse by refrigerationmdashonions, potatoes, garlic, avocado, tomatoes, bananas, stone fruit, bread, pastries, melons, spices, honey, peanut butter, apples, coffee, eggs, butter, condiments, dressings, soy sauce and hot sauce should neverbe refrigerated. Surprised . You dont know how to store your cooking oilsSome cooking oils are best stored in the cabinet, while others can be refrigerated. Credit: Getty   Angelina ZinovievaCooking oils sourced from fruits, vegetables, nuts, and seeds each have dferent storage needs. Exposure to oxygen, light or heat will subject oil to oxidation, eventually turning it rancid. While some cooking oils can be stored at room temperature, others do best when stored in the fridge.Corn and rapeseed oils:These do just fine stored in a cool, dark cabinet, or you can refrigerate themit takes more than a year to get through a bottle.Olive oil:Leaving olive oil out on the counter or a table, especiallythe bottle gets direct sunlight, or storing it on or near a stove are surefire ways to turn it rancid quickly. Place it in the coolest, darkest place in your home or use a smaller glass bottle in the kitchen.Peanut oil:Can be kept for as long as two yearsstored tightly capped and away from heat and light. Keeping peanut oil in the fridge may extend shelf le even further.Coconut oil:Very stable andhas a shelf le of two years or more.Avocado, grapeseed, hazelnut, sesame, truffle, walnut, safflower and sunflower:Delicate oils that are especially prone to rancidity, especiallyexposed to too much light or heat. Refrigerating after opening is recommended. Kept cold, these oils will remain viable for six months or more.. Youre using the wrong containers to store your foodWe tested the best-selling plastic and glass food storage containers on the market to find the best of the lot. We dropped them onto a linoleum floor, froze them, microwaved them, stained them, pried them apart, stacked them back together, and lots more.Best glass container:Pyrexs Cook and Eat Glass Storage Setisa great choice. Food wont leak, and the glass wont shatter. While the BPA-free lids maystain, they will come clean after a run in the dishwasher. Therersquos a vent for microwave reheats and, as long as the contents are defrosted, itrsquos also preheated oven safe.Best plastic container:Rubbermaidrsquos Easy Find Lidscontainers wonrsquot spring a leak unless you shake them violently, and drops arenrsquot a problem unless the container happens to fall on its side or a corner. No plastic container is oven-safe, but the set is marked dishwasher- and microwave-safe and carries a letime warranty. You should avoid freezing this set, as expanding food may pop the lid.. Youre incorrectly storing fruits and veggiesDo you know which vegetables should stay at room temperature, which should be kept inside a salad drawer, and which should never be stored together  Are you sure Do not refrigerate:Potatoes, onions, garlic, winter squash, tomatoes, bananas, peaches, plums, avocados, mangoes, melons, apples, pears, kiwis, and citrus. Exceptions include freezing for smoothies, or refrigerating for brief periods when theyre close to spoiling.Keep separate:Produce that emits high levels of ethylene gas, including ripe bananas, apples, stone fruit , cantaloupe, honeydew melons, mangoes, pears, ripe kiwis, tomatoes, onions, and leeks.Store alone:Ethylene-sensitive produce, including aubergine, broccoli, Brussels sprouts, cabbage, carrots, caullower, cucumber, leafy greens, peas, peppers, squash, sweet potatoes, strawberries, and watermelon.,params: .push. Youre letting your avocados turn brownThere are many ways to store a cut avocado, but only one that will actually keep it from browning and preserve the flavour: Leave the pit in an avocado, and tightly wrap the half in plastic wrap to keep the flavour and texture intact.. Youre letting the food in your fridge accidentally freezeFoods in your fridge shouldnt be freezing. Credit: Getty   IssaurinkoBiting into frozen food thatrsquos merely supposed to be refrigerated isnrsquot just annoying: Freezing can completely alter the taste and texture of your food. And itrsquos probably because yoursquore probably arranging your fridge the wrong way.Check your fridges temperature settings:The ideal temperature range for the interior of your fridge is degC and below.Determine problem areas:According to appliance manufacturer GE, the most common problem areas are the top shelf, the bottom of the fridge , and door shelves.Avoid vents:Most fridges have a cooling vent above the top shelf. This is where most of the cold air comes from, so keeping food away from here may prevent freezing. Adjust your freezer:Turn up your freezer temperature settings, but nothing north of degF, which will facilitate bacterial growth and accelerate food spoilage.Check your ice maker:Make sure that your ice maker is not constantly running. This could make your freezer too cold and subsequently cause your refrigerated foods to freeze.Stock up your fridge:Refrigerators need to be well-stocked to absorb all of the cold air being vented into the cavity. If it is relatively empty, all of the cold air will sink to the bottom of the cavity and freeze your food. A fully stocked fridge will help maintain temperatures and, as a result, use less energy.. Youre not fixing a door that wont shut properlyIf your fridge door wont close, its probably due to an old, dried-out gasket, the rubber seal that runs along its edge. Luckily, the fix is simple: wash the gasket, and apply petroleum jelly to the rubber to revitalize the old rubber.. Youre not regulating your fridges temperatureA full fridge will help keep the temperature consistent. Credit: Getty   Group StudioDid you know your fridge could actually be making you sick  To keep food out of what the Food Saftey Agency calls lsquothe danger zonersquo, it needs to remain below degC. The freezer should be set to -degC to keep freezer burn at bay. If your fridge and freezer are regularly warmer than those temperatures, yoursquore risking faster spoilage. Here are a few things you can do to keep your fridge properly chilled:Invest in a fridge thermometer.To use, place the thermometer in a cup of water. Why  Your refrigerator measures the temperature of the air around your food, but you want to simulate the temperature inside your foods. Check the thermometer after  hours and then, adjust the temperature of each appliance based on the results.Check to make sure the gasket is in good shape, and seals well.If you can open the door with one finger, your seal isnt tight enough. A leaky seal is an energy waster, and may be a risk to your food.Dust your refrigerators cooling coils,theyre visible. You can use a long, skinny brush made for this purpose.Cover your food.For example, leave eggs in their carton, not in the door.Keep a full fridgeto retain the cold, but leave enough room for air to circulate.The product experts at Reviewedhave all your shopping needs covered. title: castle-near-borders-now-tartan
story: A CASTLE near the Borders has ordered a new tartan to be created as part of its major refurbishment.Colin Frame, , began working to bring Biggars Shieldhill Castle back to le in January after growing up around the old fortress and hosting his wedding there in .After the castle fell into disrepair, Mr Frame saw its potential as a "bespoke wedding venue", giving couples the opportunity to "take over the whole place"."I grew up in the area near the castle," Mr Frame said. "When it was repossessed , it was empty for two years."I walked in and thought it had gone downhill. The property has a lot of neglect."Mr Frame, with his team of friends and local workers, has already managed to refurbish and decorate the ground floor of the hotel, which is due to open in September.The majority of rooms have been decorated, and remaining rooms will be completed by .As part of bringing the castle back to le, Shieldhill Castle has enlisted the help of world-renowned designers, Calzeat, of Biggar, to create a unique tartan to be used across the hotel in upholstery."Weve got a rich history of Scottish history here," said Mr Frame."The ability to customise our own pattern, not to be recreated by anyone , was really important."Calzeat director Bob Galbraith was excited to work with Shieldhill on the tartan project.He said: "I feel that it is very important to collaborate on this new and exciting project with a beautul local hotel."Apart from the very important relationship between the hotel and our mill, it gives the local community a chance to see our product in situ on their doorstep."The colours and layout of the tartan turned out just as we had hoped and definitely emulates the colours of the beautul, local countryside, as well as incorporating the corporate colours of the Shieldhill."Itrsquos a classic combination."The creation of the hotels tartan, as well as its rebuilding work, were completed during lockdown.But Mr Frame was pleased to tell this newspaper that although working during lockdown has been "hugely challenging across the UK", his team has still been able to operate under the restrictions.He explained: "We wouldnt have been open now anyway ."Weve managed to work around the restrictions and undertake the refurbishments ourselves."Mr Galbraith added: "Itrsquos been extremely dficult running a business during lockdown and wersquove to adapt in ious ways to survive through these dficult times."The new collaboration with the Shieldhill has been very rewarding in more ways than one."

title: property-patter-give-home-facelift-budget---living-room-bedroom
story: Last week we covered off the two most expensive rooms in any home, the kitchen and bathroom.But in part  of our lsquoHow to give your home a facelt on a budgetrsquo, wersquore going to give you some great ideas to update your bedrooms, living room and even hallway.BedroomsWhen it comes to styling your bedroom, the best way to inject some colour and style, whilst keeping costs down, is to add it through your accessories. Keep your wall colours neutral, like white and grey, but use your curtains, bedding and cushions to inject splashes of colour.Buying new bedding and hanging a new set of curtains can cost a lot less than a few tins of paint once you factor in all the rollers and brushes yoursquoll need to buy, plus it will take less time too.Once yoursquove bought the cushions, next time yoursquore thinking about changing the colour, just buy new covers and match the size of the cushions. That means you can store the others away, pass them on to a friend or use them in another room.Donrsquot forget about artwork. You can find some really trendy prints online and IKEA is great for cheap frames too. Make sure you buy the same size prints each time, meaning you can keep the same frames. You can update the frames easily too with a cheap can of spray paint.Canrsquot afford a new carpet  Yoursquoll be amazed at what a good deep clean and adding a colourful or patterned rug can do.If your furniture is looking a bit tired, upcycle with a lick of paint and new door handles. You can pick up a tin of furniture paint from most hardware stores or online and you can buy cute, quirky doorknobs from eBay or Etsy, or even just try spray painting the existing ones.Metal accessories like curtain rods and light fittings can benefit from that spray paint too!Upcycling is a great way to keep costs low, give a much loved item a new lease of le and is good for the environment by cutting out waste.Living roomMoving on to the most used room in the house, this can be the most dficult to update as it no doubt has many uses. From the TV room to the playroom to the dining room, your living space probably needs to be more practical than anything . But you can still add some style along the way.Your sofa likely dominates the room and can be the most expensive piece in the room ndash with the exception of the TV! So replacing this often can be costly. But have you considered replacing the covers  If your sofa is in generally good condition but itrsquos looking a bit off-colour, you can buy covers that fit over the top.IKEA do a range of these covers that are made for their sofa ranges, but you can find places online that offer made to measure services. This can be more expensive, but definitely cheaper than buying a whole new sofa and are machine washable! Alternatively, adding a new throw and some scatter cushions can have the same effect.Many of the tips for the bedroom can be used in the living room too. Like adding a nice feature wall for a splash of colour or why not try adding a nice gallery wall with lots of family pictures  A great way to add a personal touch to a room. You can even get the family involved to pick out their favourite pictures.,params: .pushPlants are a great way to brighten up a room and fill any unused corners. Donrsquot worry, it doesnrsquot mean another mouth to feed, there are plenty of really great looking fake ones to buy.Have you tried shopping from other rooms in your house  Yoursquod be surprised at how much you can change your rooms by simply swapping the accessories about.HallwayTherersquos nothing nicer than a warm welcome so donrsquot forget your hallway when yoursquore giving your home a makeover.If itrsquos on the small size then good advice is to keep it nice and bright to give the illusion of space and add colour by adding some prints to the wall, some useful hanging hooks and even a funky doormat.Everything in your hallway needs to have a practical use, but that doesnrsquot mean it has to be boring.You can add plants here too butyoursquore limited on floor space, why not try some hanging baskets or small potted plants on shelves.Maybe go the extra mile and paint the doors in your hallway  This trend is becoming more popular, with people opting for painting their doors and skirting boards, from pink to yellow and even black.Hopefully, these tips have given you some DIY inspiration to give your home a little low-cost makeover.

title: online-edinburgh-festival-12-must-see-shows-events
story: IT WAS almost inevitable that Edinburghs family of art festivals would be a casualty of the coronavirus pandemic ndash and just as inevitable that the organisers of those same festivals, as well as the artists, performers, musicians and actors who make them what they are, would respond accordingly.Thats exactly what has happened.You cant generally hit pause and play at the same time, but the Edinburgh Festival has managed it for its  iteration, with a rich, brave and pioneering programme of mostly digital and online events with here and there a visual treat for capital residents and those tourists who have decided to come anyway.The theatres may be dark but, as the programme makes clear, the artistic light burns bright regardless.My Light Shines On DisplayAs well as being the umbrella title for much of the digital offering from this yearrsquos Edinburgh International Festivalndash Kirsty Wark fronts the programme, which features a performance by Scottish Chamber Orchestra cellist Su-a Lee ndash My Light Shines On is also a light display project which will illuminate the cityrsquos famous festival venues.Using beacons of light which will be visible from vantage points across the capital it has been created by Scottish lighting designers Kate Bonney and Simon Hayes, the duo behind Pitlochryrsquos Enchanted Forest and the Electric Glen in East Renfreshire.The inspiration is the tradition of the so-called lsquoghost lightrsquo in which a light is left on in a theatre even when the venue is lsquodarkrsquo, as all theatres currently are. Andyoursquore wondering about where title came from, itrsquos a line from Primal Screamrsquos  song Movinrsquo On Up.www.e whats-on  mylightshinesonDeclanA companion piece, of sorts, to the Traverse Theatrersquos  hit Mouthpiece, written by Kieran Hurley and a keen dissection of class and culture in the capital.Here, Mouthpiece actor Lorn Macdonald turns director to re-work the two-hander in order to concentrate on the character he played, the titular Declan, a -year-old aspiring artist.Using footage shot on the Edinburgh streets plus animation and elements of the Mouthpiece script, he fleshes out Declanrsquos le and experiences. The resulting film forms part of the Traverse Digital Festival  and will be available to watch on demand later in the month.From August www.traverse declanEdinburgh International Book FestivalThe Booker Prize-winning author of Girl, Woman, Other recently became the first British woman of colour to top the UK paperback fiction chart and in the wake of the murder of George Floyd therersquos a sharp topicality to her novel, which follows the lives of  mostly black women across the years.In this special event, to be broadcast from the Edinburgh International Book Festivalrsquos Edinburgh studio, she discusses her work with the First Minister, who has written warmly about Eisto and is no stranger to the book festival  herself. Doubtless there will also be some chat about the topic occupying Ms Sturgeonrsquos time during her day job, the ongoing public health emergency caused by coronavirus.The event is free to watch online though registration is required for anybody who wants to ask a question through the QAor to participate in the chatroom. Andyou miss the event, it and most of the many other author events will remain online for the duration of the book festival.August , .pmwww.edbookfestLes Amazones DrsquoAfrique: A Virtual Live PerformanceAn lsquoas liversquo gig by musical powerhouse Les Amazones DrsquoAfrique, the multi-lingual, politically conscious all-female collective who blend hip-hop and RB with the traditional sounds of their Malian homeland.A bona fide supergroup ndash a founding member is Mariam Doumbia of Amadou  Mariam, and regular helpmates include the great Angeacutelique Kidjo ndash the band released their second album, Amazones Power, to great acclaim earlier this year and are bringing through an army of young talent in their wake.Part of the My Light Shines On strand, you can watch the band on the EIFrsquos dedicated YouTube channel from .pm on August .August  onwardswww.youtube user edinburghintfestivalEdinburgh Art FestivalEdinburghrsquos thoroughfares will this year bedevoid of crowds, buskers and whatever you call those people who persistently thrust flyers under your nose, but the special vibe of the festival streets is being re-created to an extent by an array of outdoor interventions from the Edinburgh Art Festivalas part of its Around The City strand.EAF favourite Peter Liversidge has recreated his  project Flags For Edinburgh ndash  flags saying HELLO will fly from buildings across the capital ndash and where there are billboard-mounted artistic interventions both whimsical and political. Keep your eyes peeled.Various venueswww.edinburghartfestivalFringe On FridayRunning on Fridays throughout what would have been the Edinburgh Fringe, this paid-for,  minute iety style show-cum-fundraiser gives you a slice of what might have been.The virtual curtain goes up at pm, tickets cost poundand among the acts confirmed so far are David OrsquoDoherty, Lost Voice Guy and Tf Stevenson.From August www.edfringeChamber Music Soundscapes In Princes Street GardensEvery weekday at pm from Monday the EIF will mount a live concert featuring a range of top chamber musicians, the only dference from normal festival fare being that the musicians will be in The Hub, EIFrsquos headquarters at the top of the Royal Mile, and the audience will be in Princes Street Gardens listening via an array of speakers .,params: .pushAmong the musicians lined up to play are members of the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra , the Elias String Quartet , the Dunedin Consortand, kicking things off on Monday, tenor Nicky Spence and pianist Malcolm Martineau performing Shakespearean Songs. As ever, you can watch on the EIF YouTube channel.August -, Princes Street Gardenswww.e whats-on  chambermusicprincesstreetgardenswww.youtube user edinburghintfestivalDouglas StuartShuggie Bain, Douglas Stuartrsquos searing tale about a desolate childhood in Thatcherrsquos Glasgow, has been longlisted for the Booker Prize ndash not bad for a debut novel, even one which took its author  years to complete.Here, the Glasgow-born writer and former menswear designer talks to fellow Scot Damian Barr about growing up gay on a Glasgow housing scheme, his unlikely hero Shuggie Bain and the prospect of literary fame.Featuring as part of the Edinburgh International Book Festivalrsquos Made In Scotland series, the event is free to watch online though registration is required for anybody who wants to ask a question through the QAor to participate in the chatroom.August , .pmwww.edbookfestGhost LightScreening as part of the EIFrsquos My Light Shines On strand, this collaborative film by Edinburgh-based director Hope Dickson Leach and the National Theatre of Scotlandrsquos artistic director Jackie Wylie features a cast which includes James McArdle, Siobhaacuten Redmond, Thierry Mabonga and Anna Russell-Martin.Described as a love letter to Scottish theatre it draws on work by writers such as JM Barrie, David Greig, Rona Munro and Jackie Kay, as well as original compositions by Glasgow-based singer-songwriter Patricia Panther.From August www.e whats-on  nts-ghostlightwww.youtube user edinburghintfestivalAn Evening With Scottish BalletNo EIF programme would be complete without a rich menu of dance to choose from and as often as not the national company is one of those helping to provide it.And so it is in , though Scottish Balletrsquos contribution to the My Light Shines On strand is made up of a series of filmed pieces drawing on old workand existing filmed work .But the showstopper is a world premiere in the form of Catalyst, created by Scottish Ballet soloist Nicholas Shoesmith and performed on the stage of theFestival Theatre. The entire programme is available to view online from .pm on August .From August www.e whats-on  scottishballet-filmwww.youtube user edinburghintfestivalHilary MantelIn this book festival event, filmed at Mantelrsquos home in England, arts journalist Charlotte Higgins talks to the double Booker Prize winner about The Mirror And The Light, the third and final instalment in her trilogy of works about politickingth century English lawyer Thomas Cromwell.Wolf Hall and Bringing Up The Bodies are both award-winning bestsellers and nobodyrsquos betting against Mantel picking up a third Booker for The Mirror And The Light when the winner is announced in September. The event is free to watch online.August , .pmwww.edbookfestEdinburgh Festival Chorus: Carmina BuranaThe festival wouldnrsquot be the festival without the massed voices of Edinburgh Festival Chorus booming out from the choir stalls of the Usher Hall.Here the -strong choir performs two movements from Carl Orffrsquos much-loved work ndash O Fortuna and Ecce Gratum ndash though each member has rehearsed, performed and recorded their part in their own home.The resulting audio and visual material has been mixed by a sound engineer and film editor and turned into a sort of choral mosaic. It should be no less impressive as a result. The film is available to watch from .pm on August From August www.e whats-on  chorus-carminaburanawww.youtube user edinburghintfestival

title: school-opens-jedburgh-grammar-campus-welcomes-pupils
story: JEDBURGH Grammar Campus welcomed pupils to its pound million site this week.The new campus had been due to open in April, but the coronavirus pandemic forced plans to change.Yet on Wednesday , some pupils were able to enjoy their new classrooms at last, with the rest following yesterday .Jedburgh Grammar Campus head teacher Susan Oliver said staff were ldquodelighted to welcome pupils through the door, adding: ldquoWersquore in no doubt itrsquos been worth the wait."On Wednesday, the school welcomed nursery children, as well as pupils from primary one, S and S. All other pupils attended on Thursday.Other Borders schools reopened on Tuesday .The new Jedburgh site was built as part of the Schools for the Future programme launched by Deputy First Minister John Swinney in .The campus, which is open to pupils aged two to , replaces Jedburgh Grammar School and Parkside and Howdenburn primary schools.It boasts a G hockey pitch, a G sports pitch and a rural skills area.Parts of the building will allow public access, which will be monitored by Live Borders.The local charity will run sports and leisure facilities at the school, which are currently only available for outdoor activities in line with COVID- restrictions.Eventually, the public will also be allowed to use the campus for indoor activities, with library visits permitted too.Scottish Borders Councilleader Shona Haslam said: "Jedburgh Grammar Campus is a fantastic asset, with the equipment and facilities on offer providing a first-class learning environment for young people."I must thank all families in the Jedburgh area for their understanding and patience during this extremely challenging period."Mrs Haslam added: "We realise there will be some anxiety amongst pupils and parents carers arriving at the new campus, particularly in the current circumstances."However, I can assure them our first priority is the safety of pupils and staff, with a number of new COVID--related arrangements and routines in place.ldquoI also know our campus staff have worked extremely hard to help children settle into their exciting new learning space."Although Jedburgh Grammar Campus opened for pupil access on Thursday, an official opening of the site will be arranged when coronavirus guidelines are reduced to permit larger gatherings.Councillor Carol Hamilton, SBCrsquos executive member for children and young people, said: "Jedburgh Grammar Campus will provide signicant educational and wellbeing benefits for children, young people, families and the wider community in one location."For more information on the Jedburgh Grammar Campus, including FAQs, a video tour of the campus and guide on how to book leisure activities on-site with Live Borders, visit: title: property-patter-make-home-feel-bigger-simple-tricks
story: During lockdown, many homes have had todouble up as offices, schools and even play areas.Although this may have been a temporary measure, you might find that you need some extra, permanent, space in your existing house.With some imagination and a surprisingly small budget, yoursquoll be amazed at what you can achieve without having to up sticks and move.StorageDo you have the room space but just too much stuff  For starters, it sounds obvious, but do a big clear out. With recycling centres and charity shops open again therersquos no excuse. Spend the weekend sorting through any unwanted items and donate where you can.For storage solutions, you need to think outside the box ndash literally. Vacuum bags are ideal, they normally come in multipacks of ious sizes and are really cheap. Great for anything soft that is taking up a lot of space. Winter clothes, quilts and blankets can be reduced to a tenth of the size and slide under the bed nicely.If floor space is a problem, then the sky is the limit. Consider storing items that arenrsquot needed on a regular basis above units or wardrobes. Think about shelving units that are tall and slim, rather than long and bulky.Cheap and cheerful plastic, canvas or cardboard boxes can help to keep everything in place while adding a splash of colour and style. Perfect for keeping clutter off the floor.Shelves above radiators are a great way to use otherwise wasted space.If the kids are desperate for some space, a reading nook or kids study area can easily be achieved under the stairs or a window. A simple storage box with a couple of cushions on top will create a comfy seat and can double up as extra storage.Hooks can be attached to pretty much anything like bedroom doors and inside cupboards ndash again keeping items off the floor will create the illusion of more space. In the kitchen, using hooks to hang pots and pans and magnets for knives can free up cupboard space and make a statement.Knowing where things are is half the battle when considering storage options, so think about clear plastic boxes or bags that are easy to see into and can be labelled.Flexible furniture like extendable dining tables, sofa beds and even clothes rails are ideal as they have multiple uses and can be stored away easily when not in use.Let there be lightLighting and mirrors are your friends when it comes to making a smaller room feel bigger. Change large floor lamps for smaller wall lights and when it comes to wall colour, stick to pale colours and swap out heavy curtains with blinds. Luckily, a big tub of value white paint goes a long way. Let in as much light as possible, give the windows a good scrub and update yellowing lightbulbs to bright white.OutdoorsIs it time to rethink that huge sofa set and professional sized goal posts  When buying furniture, think small, light and foldable so that they can be stored away in a shed or cupboard or easily moved around. Updating your garden furniture doesnrsquot need to cost the earth, yoursquoll find some really great bargain sets in supermarkets like Aldi, Asda and Tesco and homeware stores like BM.Another way to make it feel bigger is to simply give it a good tidy. Yoursquoll be surprised at how much space you do have after clearing out those unwanted flowerpots, cutting the grass and trimming back the hedges.Your home is an investment, to be enjoyed for a long time and with these simple but effective ideas, you can enjoy the space you have for longer.

title: young-people-scotland-can-get-250-free-starting-new-job
story: Young people across Scotland could be in line for as much as pound free from the Government for starting a new job, thanks to a new benefit.Its hoped the payment, which is open for applications from today, will help young people with the financial dficulties of starting a new job - including buying new clothes, travel and get childcare.It is estimated around  young people will benefit from the new financial support in its first year.What is the benefit The Job Start Payment is a one-off sum of pound for  to -year-oldsthey have been unemployed for at least six months.The upper age limit rises to  for care leavers and the payment increases to poundthe person has a child.How can I qualy for the payment To qualy for the payment, which will be delivered by Social Security Scotland, the person applying must have received a job offer for paid employment.They must be out of paid work and must have been receiving one of the qualying benefits for six months or more at the time of the job offer:Income-based Jobseekerrsquos AllowanceIncome SupportIncome-related Employment and Support AllowanceUniversal CreditWhat has the Scottish Government said Social Security Secretary Shirley-Anne Somerville said: ldquoI am delighted that our Job Start Payment is today now open for applications it really couldnrsquot come at a better time to support our young people to take up job offers.ldquoYoung people are among those whose job prospects have been hardest hit by this pandemic. As such, it is crucial that we support them and ensure they are at the heart of our economic recovery from Covid-.She added: ldquoGetting a job can represent a massive turning point for many young people, but it can also bring financial pressures.ldquoCosts like travel, new work clothes, or childcare often have to be met before people get their first pay.ldquoThe brand-new Job Start Payment will help young people with these costs, which can sometimes be a barrier to them taking up an offer, and we will be encouraging anyone eligible to apply.Full details can be found on the Scottish Government website here.

title: wearing-face-mask-reduces-spread-covid-19-coughing-speaking
story: Wearing a face covering lowers the risk of spreading Covid- to others through speaking and coughing, new research suggests.Speaking and coughing without face protection exposes people nearby to droplets carrying the virus that could otherwise be stopped by wearing a mask, according to the study.Researchers found someone standing two metres from a coughing person with no mask is exposed to , times more droplets than someone half a metre from someone coughing and wearing a covering.Lead researcher Dr Ignazio Maria Viola, of the University of Edinburghrsquos School of Engineering, said: ldquoWe knew face masks of ious materials are effective to a dferent extent in filtering small droplets.ldquoHowever, when we looked specically at those larger droplets that are thought to be the most dangerous, we discovered that even the simplest handmade single-layer cotton mask is tremendously effective.ldquoTherefore wearing a face mask can really make a dference.Scientists at the university compared the number of droplets that landed on a surface in front of a person coughing and speaking without and with a surgical mask or a basic cotton face covering.Tests were carried out on people and a le-sized anatomical human model connected to a machine that simulates coughs and speech.Analysis found that the number of droplets was more than , times lower when wearing even a single layer cotton mask, the researchers say.They add that the findings, published on a non-peer reviewed preprint server, could have implications for social distancing measures.Professor Paul Digard, of the University of Edinburghrsquos Roslin Institute, said: ldquoThe simple message from our research is that face masks work.ldquoWearing a face covering will reduce the probability that someone unknowingly infected with the virus will pass it on.According to the scientists their results contrast with previous research that suggested masks are less effective.However, these studies also measured small droplets ndash known as aerosols ndash which can remain airborne for hours.How much virus transmission takes place by aerosol is still not known, but the team cautions thatit is found to be signicant, the new findings overestimate the protective effects of face coverings.However, for bigger droplets carrying the largest amount of virus, masks are extremely effective in reducing spread to the immediate surroundings, researchers say.Dame Ottoline Leyser, chief executive, UK Research and Innovation , said: ldquoThe Covid- pandemic is a crisis that has impacted virtually everybody. In these extraordinary circumstances we have seen the value of rapid and collaborative research in supporting our response to the crisis.ldquoThe findings published today from a study led by researchers at the University of Edinburgh and co-funded by UKRI support the growing body of evidence that face coverings reduce Covid- transmission via respiratory droplets.ldquoResearch into Covid- is obviously a relatively new field, with the science still evolving. New information about the virus plays a crucial role in informing policy makers and the public.The study was funded by the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council, the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council, the European Commission and Japan Student Services Organisation..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Wearing a face mask  ureduces spread of Covid- through coughing and speaking u

title: love-first-sight-couple-toast-golden-anniversary
story: Norman and Sophia Taylor enjoyed a socially distanced golden wedding anniversary, due to the Covid- restrictions, at their home on North Grange Avenue on July  with their three children.Northumbrian-born Norman, who turned  on June , met Sophia, , in Prestonpans Royal British Legion in , saying it was ldquolove at first sight and ldquoeyes over a dance floor.The pair married shortly afterwards at Prestonpans Register Office and then went on to travel the world due to Normanrsquos job as a fitter and turner, a trade he learned in the Merchant Navy.The family travelled across Britain between  and . They then stayed in Africa between  and , including Zambia, with the children attending public school in South Africa.However, Sophia started to feel homesick so moved back to Prestonpans in .Norman then got a job in Libya, working four weeks away and then being back at home for four weeks. He worked in this job for the rest of his career, retiring  years ago.During his working le, Norman was also a delivery driver.However, after his retirement he took on the role as a golf caddy at Muirfield, near Gullane.Prestonpans-born Sophia, as Cissie to her friends, worked as a barmaid, including at the former Lady Susan pub in Prestonpans.When Norman married Sophia, she had three children from a previous marriage: Richard, now aged , Charles, , and Eileen, .Their grandson Kal, described as the ldquoapple of their eye, was born in  and was ldquospoiled rotten according to Sophia.Norman and Sophia have sadly been in poor health recently, with Norman suffering a heart attack this year.However, he still makes an effort to visit the Legion in Prestonpans twice a week, every Monday and Friday.When the Legionrsquos beer garden re-opened and Norman was able to go back to his favourite bar, Richard said it was ldquothe first time I have seen a smile on his face for months.Norman says the secret to a long marriage is ldquothe we is always right.Richard added: ldquoThey are totally in love. Irsquove never seen my mum and dad fight and my dad has never risen his voice once. My dad is an absolute gentleman and they absolutely dote on each other.

title: lights-vandalised-andy-scotts-dunbear-statue
story: The steel sculpture, which features a bear standing on its hind legs and is located just off the A, near the Spott Roundabout on the edge of Dunbar, was unveiled last December.A post on social media revealed that lights next to the sculpture, which measures  feet in height, had been damaged.It reads: ldquoWe are conscious that a number of lights have been deliberately damaged at the DunBear sculpture and thanks to those for reporting this to us.ldquoWe have an engineer out looking at this.ldquoThe sculpture is very much part of the community and we would be gratefulyou see anyone damaging it that this is reported to the police.The artwork was created by Andy Scott, the same man behind The Kelpies, and is a tribute to Dunbar-born John Muir, who would go on to become a key figure in the formation of the US national parks.

title: trio-entrepreneurs-celebrate-receiving-25-000-cash-boost
story: Amee Ritchie and Jake Elliot Hook, former pupils of Ross High School in Tranent, set up Srsquowheat after developing the Srsquowheat bottle ndash a reusable double-ended water bottle made from a mix of plant materials.Hannah Gordon, from Ormiston, launched Crossroad Games CIC, which creates bespoke visual novel video games for business clients while co-creating alongside marginalised young people to develop their skills.They were among  student and graduate businesses at the university which received a portion of grant aid as part of a range of support from Santander Universities UK to help them through the Covid- pandemic.Hannah said: ldquoCrossroad Games, as a member of Queen Margaret Universityrsquos Business Innovation Zone, has been developing as a start-up community interest company that will co-design visual novel video games alongside marginalised young people. During the pandemic, it has become increasingly hard to see how the business would be able to keep developing for launch during a time of lockdown and uncertainty.ldquoThe Santander Universities UK funding given to Crossroad Games has allowed us to take a step forward instead of a hesitant one backwards. The funding will be going towards developing a visual novel game demo that will showcase our product offering. We are grateful to be given that opportunity by Santander and Queen Margaret University.Dr Richard Butt, the universityrsquos deputy principal, said: ldquoAt Queen Margaret University, we are proud to support student and graduate start-ups through our Business Innovation Zone, and, more broadly to support economic development.ldquoSo we thank Santander Universities for their generous support and commitment during this challenging time.

title: musselburgh-primary-school-extension-gets-go-ahead
story: Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School, Musselburgh, plans to add a new sports hall and nursery to its already-extended building as it prepares for another increase in its school rolls.The school, which was established in , moved onto its current site in , when it was officiallyopened by Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother.However, the latest extension will mean the loss of a seven-a-side football pitch on the grounds, with plans to temporarily create a second pitch two miles away to compensate.A report by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning officers said that two pitches would be lost to the planned nursery extension, with only one being replaced on another part of the site.It said that a new-a-side sports pitch would be created on council-owned land at Whitecraig, two miles from the school, next to an already-established pitch which would be lsquorealignedrsquo to allow for the addition.And it revealed that, in the long term, it was expected thatnew public use facilities at Musselburgh Grammar School would provide a permanent alternative to the lost sports pitch.The report said: ldquoSportscotland have been consulted on the application and have no objection, being satisfied that loss of a seven-a-side sports pitch at Pinkie St Peterrsquos will be mitigated by the temporary provision of an -a-side sports pitch on land at Whitecraig and the subsequent provision of a permanent synthetic grass pitch at Musselburgh Grammar School.The new nursery will also be built over the current car park access, meaning a new vehicle access will need to be built off Pinkie Road, which runs alongside the school site.Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School currently has just under  children attending school and nursery.In , it was given the go-ahead to add a single-storey extension to accommodate its growing school roll, with a secondlarger extension approved the following year.The most recent application, which received no objections, will see a new sports hall to the north of the building and nursery playrooms to the east.There will also be additional car parking spaces and cycle park facilities.

title: call-extend-20mph-limit-past-seton-sands
story: East Lothian Council has introduced lower speed limits in many towns and villages ndash including Cockenzie and Port Seton ndash as part of a project to make the streets safer for pedestrians and the increased number of cyclists who are being seen out and about.It is also creating a temporary cycle path between Cockenzie and Port Seton and Prestonpans which will run along the north side of the B coast road.Community councils in these areas have welcomed these changes, which were announced after the local authority received pound.million in funding from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Spaces for People initiative.However, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council has called for its mph road speed limit to be extended to include the section of the B at Seton Sands Holiday Village, to the immediate east of Port Seton, which has been the scene of tragic road accidents in the past.Bryan Hickman, community council chairman, said while some concerns had been raised on social media about the money being spent on measures and their temporary nature, the majority of people commenting supported the changes.He said: ldquoMost people, including the community council, are in agreement. Any work that makes the roads safer for pedestrians and cyclists must be welcomed and supported.ldquoIt is felt, however, that the mph zone needs to be extended beyond Seton Sands holiday camp.ldquoThis stretch of road is very prone to speeding and has had a number of accidents, some unfortunately fatal.Brian Weddell, chairman of Prestonpans Community Council, said they, along with neighbouring community councils in Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry, had been campaigning for lower speed limits around their communities.And he said the introduction of the three-metre wide cycle lane on the coast road would be welcomed by cyclists and motorists alike.He said: ldquoWith the huge increase in cyclists on our local roads and shoppers having to queue on pavements measures aimed at slowing the speed of traffic in the town are to be welcomed.ldquoThe three community councils in the Preston Seton Gosford ward have been campaigning to get speed limits lowered on the roads around the local towns and villages and hopefully this will also be introduced by East Lothian Council.ldquoThe dedicated cycle route between Prestonpans and Cockenzie will be particularly welcomed by local children who have taken to their bikes during the pandemic. The two-way cycle path will also be appreciated by motorists who have been getting frustrated at the signicant increase of cyclists using the coast road.Additional plans under Spaces for People include installing, in the autumn, electric bike hire stations featuring eight e-bikes at two locations in Prestonpans and one in Cockenzie in autumn.

title: fundraisers-efforts-recognised-parliament
story: Alex Brown has been holding carpet and vinyl clearance sales on Tranentrsquos Bridge Street through his business Ideal Flooring Solutions.Among those benefiting are Tranent Belters and East Lothian Foodbank.Cheques for pound were presented to representatives from both of the charities last month.Kenny MacAskill, MP for East Lothian, was delighted to recognise Mr Brown, who lives in Musselburgh, for his fundraising efforts through an Early Day Motion at Westminster.It reads: ldquoThat this House applauds the fundraising efforts of Alex Brown from Musselburgh recognises that through his businessrsquos sale he has donated money to two Tranent charities, Tranent Belters and the East Lothian Foodbank understands that Alex has been involved in charitable fundraising for much of his le and encourages Alex in his intention to raise money for charities in East Lothian on a continuing basis.

title: broadband-improvements-lined-towns
story: Openreach wants to make ultra-reliable and gigabit-capable full fibre broadband available to places throughout Scotland, including Cockenzie and Port Seton, Prestonpans, Tranent, Belhaven and Dunbar.It is hoped having access to some of the fastest broadband speeds in Europe will boost post-Covid economic recovery.Robert Thorburn, Openreachrsquos partnership director for Scotland, was pleased to see work progressing.He said: ldquoWersquove already upgraded hundreds of thousands of homes and business across Scotland to full fibre.ldquoAs well as keeping the existing network running throughout the Covid- crisis, our engineers have, safely and with social distancing in place, continued building the new infrastructure to make sure that as lockdown restrictions ease, our network is there to support families, businesses and the economic recovery.Work is expected to get under way in many of the announced locations within the next - months, although, due to the size of the build, some places will see work continue into .Paul Wheelhouse MSP, the Scottish Governmentrsquos connectivity minister, said: ldquoDigital Connectivity has played a vital role in supporting our efforts to keep people safe and connected during lockdown, and will play a pivotal role in plans for our strategic economic recovery from the pandemic, maintaining jobs and livelihoods and creating new skills and opportunities.ldquoThis rollout of gigabit-capable full fibre broadband access enabled by Openreach to these more rural areas is welcomed.To view the full list of market towns and villages included in the announcement, go to www.openreach fibre-broadband

title: fundraising-cyclist-knows-east-lothian-z
story: Peter Hardie, from Tranent, took a town, village or tourist attraction for each letter of the alphabet and cycled between each one in alphabetical order.He completed the challenge on Friday, July , cycling  miles in  hours and  minutes, a faster time than expected.He initially expected to cycle  miles but, after finding some shortcuts, he shaved eight miles off his total distance.He left his house in the townrsquos Windygoul area at .am, finishing at the zebra crossing near Tranentrsquos Co-op store at .pm.Apart from grass getting stuck in the chain of his mountain bike, the ride went off without a hitch and both man and bike made it to the finishing line in one piece, enjoying the views along the way.Peter told the Courier: ldquoIrsquom still mentally tired. Afterwards I could walk round the corner but I couldnrsquot be bothered.ldquoI got lucky that I didnrsquot get any injuries. I think all my preparation worked. Irsquom pleased, really pleased.ldquoI kept passing golf courses and I am a keen golfer so was wishing I could be playing golf instead!To train for the challenge, Peter took parts of the route, for example letters A-H, and practised the cycle, figuring out his route,there were any shortcuts and any undiscovered hidden roads.One hurdle he did have to face was the road between West Fenton and Gullane being closed, meaning he had to get off his bike and walk around the barriers.On his journey, Peter visited Aberlady, Ballencrieff, Cockenzie, Drem, East Fortune, Fenton Barns, Gullane, Haddington, Ivory Clothing in Haddington, John Muir Country Park, Kingston, Longniddry, Macmerry, New Winton, Ormiston, Prestonpans, Queen Margaret University, Royal Musselburgh Golf Club, Seton Sands, Tranent, Ugston, Votadini in East Linton, Whitekirk, Lennoxlove Houseand Yester Castle before finishing at the zebra crossing.When the Courier published an article on July  previewing Peterrsquos challenge, he had not decided on a place for the letter lsquoIrsquo.He said that he debated visiting Inveresk but said doing so would add several more miles.He added: ldquoI was worried about how long I would be out for.ldquoI just thought thatI can find a place in Haddington [that starts with the letter lsquoIrsquo] then that could save a lot of miles and give myself a bit of easiness.Peter said that the challenge was also inspired by a person who had travelled on all of the buses in Edinburgh, a challenge that ldquoalways stayed in my head.He raised money for the Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity, where his partner works.So far he has raised more than pound,, double his initial pound target, with his employers HSBC also donating pound,, meaning that more than pound, will be handed over to the hospital.Peter said: ldquoI never went out of my way to say I was doing this challenge, please go and support me, but Irsquom delighted with how itrsquos gone.On doing the challenge again but potentially with dferent places, Peter said that he had not thought about it but was considering doing a dferent cycling challenge.To support Peter, visit give.everydayhero uk peters-a-z-east-lothian-crazy-cycle-challenge

title: update-expected-proposals-dunbear-park
story: Proposals for DunBear Park, on land to the rear of the townrsquos Asda store and garden centre, were unveiled to the public at the beginning of June.The public exhibition, which took place online due to coronavirus restrictions, featured drawings which highlighted the possibility of retail and leisure units, drive-thru units, and a hotel being created on the site which surrounds the DunBear sculpture, which was revealed last year.Other potential developments on the .-acre site include offices, a nursery, care home and elderly amenity flats, as well as industrial and storage units.The plans also included  low-carbon affordable homes for rent, which, according to the developers, would be aimed at key workers such as NHS staff, police and care workers.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, alerted colleagues that Hallhill Developments, which is behind the proposals, was keen to update the group.That will take place via a Zoom call at the community councilrsquos next meeting on Monday.A planning application is expected to be submitted to East Lothian Council in the near future.

title: changes-planned-high-street-scotmid-store
story: The High Street supermarket is looking to make changes inside its store, while also increasing the number of spaces in the neighbouring car park.Proposals for the store and car park are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.A spokeswoman for the business said they had discussed the project with the local community council ahead of submitting the planning application.She said: ldquoThe work being proposed will help improve our offer in the community by improving the store entrance and external appearance of the store and by refitting the store in accordance with our latest branding.ldquoWe also recognise the limitations of the existing car park and propose to make our car park larger and easier to access.ldquoWe also propose to move the funeral unit which is located in the car park into the main building.The number of spaces in the car park will nearly double as it increases from  to .Some work has already been carried out inside the store, with energy efficient refrigeration cabinets with doors installed.

title: council-urged-leave-haddington-high-street-alone
story: East Lothian Council is considering a wide range of proposals across each of the countyrsquos major towns in a bid to ensure physical distancing in the streets.It is hoped that the measures will ldquoenhance opportunities for walking and cycling, while supporting the reopening of businesses.Already, a town-wide mph speed limit has been introduced in Haddington, with the council now looking at potential changes in the town centre.Among the measures under consideration are:l On the north side of High Street , where the road is wide, move parking spaces into the carriageway. This will widen the pavement areal On the south side of High Street, widen the pavement at the western endl Re-configure parking on Market Street to increase space available for pedestrians l Alter pedestrian crossings to minimise wait time for pedestriansl Re-configure Station Road Hope Park junction to create more space for pedestriansl Introduce footpath lsquobuild-outsrsquo on West Road to provide refuges for pedestrians to step into and let others pass, and also contribute to reducing vehicle speedsl Introduce footpath lsquobuild-outsrsquo on Pencaitland Road to contribute to reducing vehicle speeds.A spokeswoman for the local authority told the Courier: ldquoThe vast majority of car parking spaces in Haddington town centre will continue to be available for use, with additional spaces currently available at John Muir House while many council staff continue to work remotely.Other measures to be explored before the end of the year include the installation of a public e-bikehire station for eight bicycles on Court Street.As the town gets busier and with pupils ing to school, other options ndash re-configuring Hardgate Victoria Terrace signals to create more space for pedestrians and closing Tynebank Road to through traffic to facilitate walking to school ndash will also be explored.Jim Graham, from the townrsquos community council and Haddington Business Community Partnership, felt that there were some positive aspects to the proposals.He backed the aspects which would make it safer for youngsters walking to and from school but added: ldquoLeave High Street alone.Mr Graham said: ldquoWe are getting lots of customers but they are coming direct to get a service, to get a watch battery or gt, to get their television repaired, buy a newspaper or get a haircut.ldquoThey come to Haddington for that purpose.ldquoI donrsquot think people want to have barriers up or cones out.ldquoWe want to make it easy for people to access High Street.Mr Graham has also been in touch with the townrsquos four councillors ndash Shamin Akhtar, Craig Hoy, John McMillan and Tom Trotter ndash as well as council staff, urging them to meet with traders to discuss the issue.

title: perseid-meteor-shower-2020-peak-week-best-time-spot
story: If skies are clear, the display of celestial fireworks should be visible across the UK from about midnight tonightuntil .am UK time on Thursday, August  - according to astronomers at Royal Observatory Greenwich.What are the Perseids The astronomical event is associated with the dusty debris left by Comet Swt-Tuttle, which orbits the sun once every  years.The meteoroids from the comet, mostly no bigger than a grain of sand, burn up as they hit the Earthrsquos atmosphere at  miles per second to produce a shooting stream of light in the sky.Peak temperatures can reach anywhere from ,C to ,C as they speed across the sky.The meteors are called Perseids because they seem to dart out of the constellation Perseus.The meteor shower began on July  and will continue to be visible until August .What have astronomers said Anna Ross, an astronomer at the Royal Observatory Greenwich, said the best time to spot the meteors is between midnight and .am on Thursday, when up to  meteors or ldquoshooting stars will be visible per hour, which is more than one every second.She told the PA news agency: ldquoThis makes the Perseids one of the most impressive meteor showers of the year.ldquoDuring the peak night of the shower, you will be able to find it in the north-east of the sky, getting higher throughout the night.ldquoYou donrsquot have to be able to see Perseus to spot meteors, however, as they will be moving away from the radiant across the whole sky in every direction.To make the most of the meteors, Ms Ross said observers should avoid well-lit and built-up areas and try to find an unobstructed view to the east.She added: ldquoFind a dark area and allow around  minutes for your eyes adapt to the dark.ldquoAs meteors move quite fast across the sky itrsquos best to look up without using telescopes or binoculars so you can see as much of the sky as possible.How regular will the meteors be The Perseids are one of the more active meteor showers on stargazersrsquo calendars, producing an average of between  and  shooting stars an hour at their peak.The shower in rsquos was especially active, delivering up to  meteors an hour at its height.While the shooting stars this year wonrsquot be quite as regular, stargazers can still expect to see around  of them an hour.Do I need special equipment to see the Perseids Meteor showers are typically visible with the naked eye, so no special equipment is needed, but those in rural areas with minimal light pollution will have a clearer view.Heading out to a dark spot is the best plan of action, but stargazers should allow around  minutes for their eyes to become accustomed to the dark.Patience is also a virtue, with shooting stars tending to appear in clusters, followed by a lull.The meteors will appear to come from the direction of the Perseus constellation in the north eastern part of the sky, although they should be visible from any point.A cloudy night could still scupper your chances of spotting any meteors, however, so keep your eye on weather forecasts.

title: new-head-education-named
story: Ms Brown is currently the chief operating officer for education with the local authority and will take the place of Fiona Robertson, who moved to a new post with Midlothian Council at the start of the year.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoLesley has a strong track record and will play a vital leadership role.
