title: lockdown social distancing changes backed penarth council announce
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThis is despite staunch challenges from some businesses in the town, who are concerned the zone, combined with a one-way traffic system around the town post lockdown, could lead to a decline in footfall.The survey ndash circulated by PTC online in July ndash has been completed by almost  people, who ldquolargely felt change was a good thing.In a meeting last Tuesday the Vale of Glamorgan Council ndash which will have the final say ndash was updated on the feedback, and reviewed plans will shortly be put to the Vale after being shared with Penarthians.These proposalsare likely to retract the idea of a pedestrianisation zone at Lower Glebe Street, instead implementing this on Windsor Road from the roundabout to Hickman Road.The town council says the new ideas will bring about  new spacesLower Glebe Street could be a ldquoshared space for delivery vehicles and disabled drivers.Council members at PTC met yesterday evening to discuss the ideas further and decide on what will be put to the Vale.Businesses on Lower Glebe Street were vocerous in their objections to the plans to incorporate the area in the safe zone, and said they have already seen a noticeable decline in sales since temporary parking restrictions were enforced for social distancing reasons.Julie Haines, owner of Jewels Canley Interiors, said she is ldquovery surprised people are backing the changes.ldquoI think all this change for the sake of a few parking spacesis a waste of money and will do little for the town, she said.Traders gathered in Lower Glebe Street two weeks ago to challenge the proposals, and the town council says they have been listened toldquoMy fear is that these plans are all well and good until it rains and people are stuck in traffic. Wersquore heading into winter and itwonrsquot be used, and most people wonrsquot be able to park near us anyway.ldquoI donrsquot think the changes are necessary.Another idea which could be retracted from the proposals is the one-way traffic system from the library to Hickman Road . This is likely to be swapped for a two-way system to allow buses and other vehicles to access Rectory Road more easily.Nigel Humphrey, councillor for St Augustines, who has been speaking atwith traders about the ideas, said: ldquoThe driver in all this is the need for a safe zone, and for Penarth to look better in a way that works for everyone.ldquoThe indication is that Penarth is united behind these ideas."This is an emergency response to help us survive a crisis, and is temporary unless someone decides otherwise.Richard Snell, owner of AB Snell Son on Stanwell Road, said: ldquoIrsquom trying to look at the bigger picture and I have warmed to some of the ideas.       ,params: .pushldquoI am glad the one-way system is being rethought. The ideas as they were would have caused congestion and rat running through Hickman Road and Arcot Street.Richard SnellldquoIn general terms I think new parking ideas are good. Most people will walk a couple of hundred yards, and will be more inclined to do thatthe volume of traffic lessens, so the safe zone would facilitate that.ldquoIrsquom behind trying to make walking around Penarth a better experience, and I donrsquot think this pedestrianisation zone will be the killer it has been built up to be."It is crucial this trial period is done properly and the thoughts of Penarthians are thoroughly taken into account on a rolling basis."Gideon Calder of environmental group Gwyrddio Penarth Greening said: "Its great to see a majority support for change."Of course, wed like to see this as part of a wider movement to promote active traveland in Penarth were very lucky that so many of us live within easy walking substance of the centre."But those are conversations for further down the line. The first crucial step is to make Penarth as safe a place as possible for people to spend time in."For more information, visithttps:www.penarthtowncouncil.gov.uk your-council penarth-post-covid-your-views-on-our-town-centre parking Are you sure you want to delete this comment Yes, delete the commentNo, keep the commentReport This CommentGet involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: minister launches welsh governments clean air plan wales improve air quality
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityPoor air quality is the biggest environmental risk to public health and also has effects on permit bioersity and the natural environment.In Wales, poor air quality contributes to a reduced le expectancy equivalent to between , and , deaths each year ndash often having a pronounced impact on the most vulnerable, such as the very young or very old, and those with respiratory and cardiovascular conditions.The Clean Air Plan identies a range of actions to be delivered by the Welsh Government and our partners to improving the nationrsquos air quality.The measures outlined in the Plan will work alongside existing schemes to reduce public exposure to air pollution.These actions will reduce air pollution, health risks and inequalities in order to improve public health.They will also support our natural environment through actions supporting bioersity and Welsh agriculture, reducing emissions from industry and creating sustainable places to live in, which will improve our quality of le.MORE STORIESConsultation launched on plans to reduce single use plastics in WalesApplication to change Barry waste wood facility permit withdrawnIncinerator protest at Senedd follows in wake of Barry biomass beginning its commissioning phaseThe Plan links strategies and initiatives which encourage more people to walk, cycle, or use public transport complementing the Active Travel Act and the Welsh Governmentrsquos Transforming Towns Initiative.Some of the measures include signicant investment in active travel infrastructure, improving rail services and supporting decarbonisation through our aim for a zero tailpipe exhaust emission taxi and bus fleet by  and investigating measures to support a reduction in personal vehicle use such as road user charging, Clean Air Zones and or Low Emission Zones.The Plan also includes implementing the electric vehicle charging strategy and supporting an increase in the proportion of vehicles which are ultra-low emissionand promoting a sht to ULEVs for waste collection. reviewing the powers local authorities have to tackle emissions from domestic burning investigating the contribution bonfires and fireworks make to levels of harmful emissions and increasing air quality monitoring through the development of a new Air Pollution Monitoring Network to protect the public, especially those most vulnerable, from air pollution.It involves intelligent tree and hedge planting alongside expanding woodlands to support air quality improvements strengthening the control of emissions in agriculture delivering enhanced behaviour change communications and producing new statutory guidance to help protect workforces from exposure to air pollution and proposals for a new Clean Air Act for Wales to enhance existing legislation and introduce new powers to further tackle air pollution.Minister for environment, energy and rural affairs, Lesley Grfiths said: ldquoI am very pleased to announce the launch of our Clean Air Plan, which sets out how we will look to improve air quality across Wales, and deal with those problems caused by air pollution, during the next  years.ldquoThe aims outlined in the Plan are there to safeguard the most vulnerable, but improving our air quality nationwide will be to the benefit of everyone in Wales, and itrsquos something we should all want and strive for. But in order to achieve that, we have to take action now.ldquoMuch of that work is already underway ndash despite the recent pandemic, we have been able to support local authorities in commencing work on schemes to improve air quality across Wales.ldquoWe know that as people across Wales have responded to those restrictions imposed due to the covid- pandemic, they have changed how they do things and taken on new habits ndash including decreasing their reliance on cars, and doing more in their local areas, rather than feeling the need to travel long distances.She added: ldquoWhile the work outlined in the plan will run across government, the measures involved cannot be achieved by government alone ndash well have a role to play in ensuring that we tackle the problems of air pollution and poor air quality.       ,params: .pushldquoWhile the Clean Air Plan will require us all to play our part in tackling poor air quality, the recent actions undertaken by the people of Wales show what we can do when we come together in order to protect the most vulnerable, and to respond to those problems which face all of us.Healthy Air Cymru chairman, Joseph Carter said: ldquoHaving been involved in the development of this plan, we are incredibly proud of what it has become."This ambitious proposal offers the opportunity to transform our country and create a greener, healthier Wales.ldquoHowever, this plan cannot be delivered overnight and will need support from everyone across Wales."Now is the time to make this issue a priority ndash this is about delivering for people and communities across Wales.ldquoWe all have a role to play in improving air quality across Wales, and through working together, we can build upon it and work together to deliver for future generations."Letrsquos make  the fresh start Wales needs, by passing this ambitious plan through a robust Clean Air Act.An earlier version of the Plan went out for public consultation in December the revised Plan in its present form follows that consultation, which lasted for  weeks.The consultation included events with stakeholders and engagement events with young people. article_url   content_id title: vaughan gething visits penarth club recognise lockdown efforts
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityMr Gething, whose son regularly attended football training in the junior section at the football club tied to the social club prior to the pandemic, stopped by to talk about the challenges that will face the club in the near future as a result of Covid-, and members explained how they have used the closure to make an even better go of le after lockdown.Dean Ford, a committee member at the club, who initially contacted Mr Gething to help mark the reopening, spoke about le during lockdown, and the challenges ahead.ldquoItrsquos been a really dficult and worrying time, and there is little doubt wersquod have closed without the support of the business grant we received, he said.The social clubis home to more than  junior footballers alone, making it the biggest footballing institution in the Vale.Dean Ford and Lee WilliamsIt is also now home to the only pub in Cogan, following the closure of The Station during lockdown.Close friends with tenants Natasha and Gareth, Mr Fordand fellow committee member Lee Williams said it compounded their concerns for the industry.ldquoItrsquos a real shame because theyrsquore great people and we were always in there, Mr Ford said. ldquoItrsquos a worrying time for pubs, but wersquove got through the worst of it hopefully, thanks I think to how cautious the Welsh Government has been."Over the past ten weeks, a group of eight volunteers have teamed up to refurbish the social club ready for Monday and beyond.The club was busy on Monday after the club asked for support on social medialdquoWe had no beer garden and all our events were cancelled, so we really would have been closed for good without the grant we received, said Mr Williams.ldquoThe only people that have been in here since March are the maintenance guys, and theyrsquove done a great job. Wersquove also really tried to push the reopening on social media and it seems to have worked.A few new faces were in on Monday afternoon, while some older friends ed to support the club too.ldquoItrsquos brilliant to see and is something we really need at the moment, Mr Williams added.Vaughan Gething speaking with membersAs a trial, the club will be opening from pm Monday to Thursday, and will continue operating from pm on Fridays and weekends.On Vaughan Gething visiting the club, Mr Ford added: ldquoItrsquos nice to have the recognition and for him to recognise wersquove suffered. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAs reported in the Penarth Times on Thursday, the town councilsaid the results show ldquowidespread backing for changes.The survey, which attracted  responses, showed  per cent of people thought there should be more outdoor space for pedestrians and businesses.Seventy-five per cent thought parking arrangements needed to change, and  per cent said the town needs to ldquoprepare for the future.Some traders, who oppose the changes ndash specically a one-way traffic system around the town and making Windsor Road and Lower Glebe Street a traffic free zone, have said the questions in the survey were too generalised and misleading.As a result of the survey, Penarth Town Council have proposed the following changes to the original ideas:Windsor Road from Arcot Street to the roundabout as a ldquoshared space for delivery vehicles and buses, with a mph speed limit.Lower Glebe Street as a ldquoshared space for delivery vehicles and disabled bays. Other vehicles should not use Lower Glebe Street as a through road.Bus stops will remain as they are. There were concerns over the impact of a bus stop on Hickman Road for traders, due to air pollution, noise pollution and congestion.A two-way system to remain on Stanwell Road from the library to the traffic lights, to allow easy access to the bus stop on Rectory Road and to prevent congestion and ldquorat running through Hickman Road and Arcot Street. A two-way system to also remain from Windsor Road to Railway Terrace.The number of parking bays has also changed. There will now be  extra bays proposed, with  of them on Plassey Street.The leader of the town council, Cllr Rhiannon Birch, explained the findings and what happens next.ldquoEven before Covid-, town centres across the country were facing issues, including the need to modernise infrastructure, and the impact of online shopping, she said. ldquoThe current pandemic has added to the scale of the challenge.ldquoThe consultation shows that a clear majority recognise the need for a degree of change in the town centre, both for it to survive in the present and to thrive in future.ldquoThe results call for the establishment of a greater degree of safe space and proposals which increase a degree of pedestrianisation whilst also increasing parking spaces.ldquoThe results show substantial agreement on these aims. Reflecting this widespread and clear response, Penarth Town Council calls on our partners in the Vale of Glamorgan Council to embrace the results and recommendations.ldquoSpecically, Penarth Town Council believes that creating a safer environment through the closure of Windsor Road to traffic for part of the day, between Arcot Street and the roundabout, including the Lower Glebe Street, would be the best way to ensure that people can feel confident about shopping safely. It would allow safe use of the space in front of shops, bars, cafes and restaurants.ldquoIt also lessens the need for one-way systems on pavements for pedestrians, which are perplexing for many and hard to implement. These proposals can be achieved in a way which also increases the amount of parking spaces available.The results will now be put to the Vales Planning Committee for consultation.For more information, visit https:www.penarthtowncouncil.gov.uk news survey-results Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: vale glamorgan library buildings reopen controlled basis
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityLibrary services were initially suspended in an effort to tackle the coronavirus before a click-and-collect service was launched in late June.That allows members to borrow books, audiobooks and DVDs on an appointment basis and even submit preference requests relating to authors or genres.Now residents will be able to access further facilities as the use of PCs and the physical browsing of books is permitted again.Initially, PCs can be booked for a -minute period once a week, with the number available reduced to allow for appropriate social distancing.Fixed time limits will also mean staff can properly sanitise machines between uses.MORE STORIESVale of Glamorgan libraries offer click and collect serviceBarry library closes in wake of coronavirus concernsVale Libraries lockdown Lit Facebook group established for book-loversIt will also be possible to secure a -minute slot to browse and select books from the libraries, with strict restrictions on the number of people admitted to the buildings at any one time.Library members can make appointments for either of these services by phone.Vale council cabinet member for education and regeneration, Cllr Lis Burnett said: ldquoWe know what a vital role our libraries play in the lives of some of our residents, especially at a time when most are spending more time at home.ldquoReading in particular is a productive and stimulating way to fill time so Irsquom delighted that we are now able to make more of our library services available again.ldquoWhile increasing numbers of people have been accessing books, resources and activities online, for many the reopening of library buildings will be very welcomelsquoOur library staff have worked hard to provide as many facilities as possible online, but I know they are looking forward to seeing familiar faces and hopefully some new ones too.ldquoResidents will be able to use PCs and visit libraries in person to browse books though both activities will be tightly controlled.ldquoSafety remains the number one priority and all appropriate measures will be in place to protect both library members and staff.During this period, chairs will be removed from the libraries to discourage sitting, toilets will be closed to the public and there will be no meetings, activities or room bookings available.Anyone entering the building will be asked to use hand gel and complete a track and trace card giving their name and contact details.Library staff will work behind protective screens when at a desk and wear visors at other times and all books will be quarantined for  hours before being cleaned and put back into circulation.Current weekday opening times will remain the same initially, with Barry and Cowbridge operating from am to pm and pm to pm, and Llantwit Major open for the second of those periods.The Libraries will also open between am and pm on Saturdays.As building improvement work is shortly due to take place at Penarth Library, that will not open in the same way as the councilrsquos other libraries.However, it will continue to offer a phone and internet click-and-collect service, as will Barry, Cowbridge and Llantwit Major.Community libraries in Rhoose, St Athan and Sully are also offering a click-and-collect service, with Dinas Powys and Wenvoe likely to join them in the near future.Some other council services will also be available face to face at the Civic Offices on an appointment basis from Monday, August .Appointments can now be made for registrars, council tax and benefits services by telephone.More details can be found at www.valeofglamorgan.gov.ukGet involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe girls, who are students at Cardf Sixth Form College and before that went to Stanwell School, have however chosen very dferent courses to study.Arianne who gained A* in French, A* in Politics, A* in History and A* in Biology is off to study Law with French Law at Mansfield College and Enyala who gained A* in Maths, A* in Physics, A* in Chemistry and A* in History has a place to study Materials Science at Queenrsquos College.As well as top academic students, Arianne has been part of the Welsh Debating Team and travelled to India and Thailand last year to represent Wales in the World Schools Debating Championships.Enyala won a Gold Crest Award in the Engineering Education Scheme Wales, played the leading role of Kenickie in the school production of Grease and is a keen pianist.Both girls are also members of Welsh National Youth Opera.After collecting her grades this morning, Arianne said: ldquoIrsquom so happy. I am so interested in how the legal world is changing and in particular looking at which laws we maintain and which we change coming out of the EU.ldquoCoupling law with French means that I can look at the international side of law and I am very much looking forward to learning more about both the British and French legal systems.ldquoIt is also very attractive to me to think about what the law should be from a moral perspective rather than just its application.Enyala by contrast was less sure of the direction she was going to take until she attended an Oxbridge conference in Swansea.ldquoThis was the first time I was introduced to material science she said. ldquoI really liked the structure of Oxfordrsquos course and the mixture of physics, chemistry and maths in the subject ndash it is very broad and follows on well from my EQP in nuclear energy.Both girls joined top school Cardf Sixth Form College on a  per cent scholarship from their local state school where they achieved  A*s each at GCSE.ldquoChanging schools has been a really good preparation for university le, Enyala said.ldquoIt has certainly made me more independent and aware of the world. When I joined Cardf Sixth Form I signed up for everything and particularly enjoyed playing music with some exceptionally talented musicians, taking part in badminton tournaments and performing in the drama productions.ldquoFor the first time Arianne and I have made separate friends, perhaps because we chose such dferent subjects.ldquoAs twins this is quite unusual as we are very alike in many ways but also have very dferent sides to our personalities.Arianne added: ldquoThe people were the best part of my school experience and everyone was really willing to learn and it was very easy to make friends. I felt welcome very quickly and the teachers were really inspiring. We are used to answering to each otherrsquos names so it was refreshing to actually have our own space and to realise that as well as being similar we also had room to develop very dferent talents.       ,params: .pushThe girls have also been busy during lockdown where they recorded a song and have learnt how to cook in readiness for university. Enyala has been teaching herself the guitar and Arianne has started to learn Spanish.Principal of Cardf Sixth Form College, Gareth Collier said: ldquoI am absolutely delighted that Enyala and Arianne have achieved places at Oxford as they will add so much to the community.ldquoBoth the girls have really inputted into le here at Cardf Sixth Form College with Arianne developing her leadership skills as a prefect and Enyala bringing a real sense of humour into her science lessons.ldquoI am very much looking forward to seeing how they develop and will certainly be inviting them back to share their experiences, which no doubt will be very dferent, with future students at the school. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log        ,params: .push-- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. from Saturday, August  up to four households will be able to join together to form a single extended household.A meal following a wedding, civil partnership or funeral will be allowed for up to  people indoorssocial distancing can be maintained.However, the Welsh Government will not be making any changes to the rules on people meeting indoors with people who arenrsquot part of their household or extended household.MORE STORIESFirst minister to set out changes to coronavirus regulations in WalesSouth Wales buildings and venues light up red to highlight industry now on Red AlertWelsh Government unveils support package to keep people in their homes and end homelessnessThis means that people should only visit pubs, restaurants, or other places indoors with people from their household or extended household.Amendments to the regulations will also come into force next week to make it obligatory for hospitality businesses and other high-risk settings to collect contact details of customers.Collecting this information is essential for Walesrsquo test trace protect strategy for testing the general public and preventing the spread of coronavirus.Placing this in the regulations will make it clear to managers of premises and to customers that collecting information of this sort is a requirement, not an option.Mr Drakeford said: ldquoWales has come together to tackle the spread of this virus and the action we have taken together has made a real dference."The number of cases continue to fall and this means we will be able introduce new changes to allow up to four households to come together and form an extended household.ldquoThese are cautious, step by step changes."We are learning from what is happening across the UK and outbreaks are mainly linked to people meeting others inside the home."That is why it is so important we donrsquot invite people outside our extended households into our homes."We have made so much progress and we mustnrsquot jeopardise this."That means we are not at a point where we should be visiting anyonersquos home at any time."Regulations on meeting outdoors were recently changed to make it easier to do, and this remains by far the safest way to meet.ldquoThere are also indications from other parts of the UK where pubs opened earlier than Wales that outbreaks have been linked to those places."If we are to avoid introducing local lockdown measures that could require the whole sector to close, it is vital we can quickly respond to any outbreaks.       ,params: .push"Providing our contact details when attending these premises will mean people can be contacted quickly by our Test Trace Protect teamsthey may have been exposed to coronavirus.ldquoOnly by us all doing our part and taking personal responsibility for our actions can we continue to tackle the scourge of coronavirus.ldquoFor iniduals, this means keeping a two metre distance from others, washing our hands often and wearing a face covering on public transport."For businesses this means taking action to protect customers, including taking their contact details so we can identy any outbreaks."While many businesses are being careful to collect contact details, there are too many reports of this not happening."As a result, we will be bringing in new regulations next week to make this compulsory.ldquoThis pandemic is far from over and we all still have a duty to do our part to keep Wales safe.The Welsh Government recently strengthened the powers local authorities have to enforce the regulations.This enables enforcement officers to issue a Premises Improvement Notice to highlight breaches and specy measures that need be taken on premises to comply with the law.Where a Premises Improvement Notice is not complied with, orthere is a serious breach, premises can be closed by issuing a Premises Closure Notice.Where notices are issued signs will be displayed in a prominent place to inform people that Others built roads and bridges."TheBurma-Thailand railway was nicknamed, lsquoDeath Railwayrsquo, after , prisoners of war and , local labourers died constructing its path."The allied civilians living in the Far East were captured and interned in camps, where women, children and men were subjected to similarly brutal conditions."For all those who survived ndash military and civilians - the wounds of war were etched firmly in their psyche for good."After the joy of Victory in Europeday, we can only imagine the courage and fortitude of those who remained at war for another three long months."The Welsh troops serving in the Far East and Pacic faced conditions theyrsquod never even heard of before."In extreme heat, in monsoons, alongside mosquitos and facing tropical disease, their battle was quite extraordinary."Collaboration with allies was key to success. Indian, Myanmarese, Nepali and troops from across the African continent, led the effort in South East Asia with Australian, New Zealand, Pacic Islanders, US and Canadians in the South West and Central Pacic."Many other nations also contributed."Around  per cent of personnel of the main army in South East Asia ndash the th Army - hailed from modern day India, Pakistan and Bangladesh."The contribution of volunteers across the nations was staggering. The Indian Army, had grown to . million members by the end of the war, making it the largest volunteer army in history."After the elation of VE day, some Welsh troops who survived the Far East felt like the lsquoForgotten Armyrsquo."They had served so far away, cut off from their loved ones and any contact with the world they had known."The focus at home had firmly been on Europe they could be forgiven for thinking their efforts had been forgotten."Tragically, many who died were left in those foreign fields, in unmarked graves."On Victory in Japanday, those in the Far East were still overseas, or on board a ship in the middle of the ocean like Stan Smith from Barry, weeks or months from home."Those who ed were changed forever by their experiences."He added: "On Saturday, we will mark this important anniversary and pay tribute to all those affected by the war in the Far East and Pacic: Service personnel, their families and all civilians around the world.       ,params: title: autumn date set opening new south lake leisure centre
story: Conleth Kane’s new debut album rockets to top ten in chartsPolice investigate financial irregularities at churchNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleAutumn date set for opening of new South Lake Leisure CentreA date has been set for the opening of the new south lake leisure centre in Craigavon with the multi-million-pound facility to open its doors on November .By The NewsroomTuesday, th July , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th July , : pm""The largest capital project to date undertaken by ABC Council, and among the largest in Northern Ireland, the new multi-use sports and leisure complex is described by the council as a major new flagship health and wellbeing destination.Work on the facility was halted by the coronavirus outbreak. Since ing to site Farrans, the contractor in charge of the build, has ensured the contract is completed ready for opening in the Autumn.Farrans has been spearheading the build since initial enabling works got under way early in , creating  jobs on site during construction as part of a project which has delivered at least £. million in direct wages to the local economy.Located at the south side of Craigavon’s balancing lake, the facility is a landmark venue for the area and is situated within a pre-existing network of walking and cycling paths covering around three miles. The council hopes the new leisure centre will welcome visitors from across the borough and beyond to its new -metre pool, a young children’s indoor leisure water feature, a ,m state-of-the-art gym, multiple studios, health and wellbeing suite, sensory room, eight-court sports halls, spin studio, soft play area and an on-site café.It also incorporates an outdoor water sports provision offering a wide range of water based activities including windsurfing, water skiing and paddle sports. The council says the scale of South Lake Leisure Centre has been future-proofed to meet the needs of a growing population and a raising demand from a range of leisure, amateur and professional sporting enthusiasts.Lord Mayor of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon, Councillor Kevin Savage, sai: “With a confirmed opening date just  weeks away, I am delighted that this stunning new centre - which will have fabulous facilities for everyone in the borough to access and enjoy - is almost complete.“South Lake Leisure Centre provides a once-in-a-generation opportunity to transform and dramatically enhance the quality of health and leisure provision within the borough, providing community access for everyone to the best facilities available in the UK and Ireland.”As part of the preparations for the official opening of South Lake Leisure Centre, interim arrangements have been agreed for leisure facilities in Portadownand Brownlow . Cascades Leisure Complex will be open to the public for lane swimming only in August, remaining open until Saturday th October.Craigavon Leisure Centre will remain open to the public for gym only until Monday th October. Waves Leisure Complex will be closed to the public.When all these facilities, which are approaching the end of their al le close, leisure staff will begin their training at the new South Lake Leisure Centre building.""Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us onExploreNewsSportWhats OnLestyleMore from Portadown TimesAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoDirectoryLocal GuideReader ShopUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessAdvertise a JobPlace your AdSubscribeEventsArchiveReaders Charter" fill"#ea"©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-gxMtzJ sc-dfVpRl dLpuYr"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policyNews you can trust since News" class"expand" role"button" tabindex""""" scale translate " points"  .  . title: bridal suite opened ni charity new and pre loved gowns

When we were investing in developing the Wedding Suite we wanted to create a welcoming environment where brides could visit with their bridal party and enjoy the experience of choosing their wedding dress without any pressure.”Anne Crossan, Regional Retail Manager, SVP NI, said: “The new Vincent’s Wedding Suite is a wonderful addition to the service that we are providing to the local community in the Portadown area. I think it’s really important that brides feel comfortable and enjoy the experience of buying their wedding dress and being able to offer private appointments is a lovely way of personalising the experience for them and their families. I wish Michael and the staff well with this new offering for the store.”The Wedding Suite at Vincents PortadownBrides wishing to visit Vincent’s Wedding Suite can be accommodated by appointment during normal shop opening hours and also on evenings and at weekends. Mayor, Councillor Kevin Savage said: “Shared history events are important for a ided society.“We hope that by embracing social media and digital technology we can attract wider audiences comprised of people who – for ious reasons – might not normally attend such an event in person.“With COVID- still very much a concern at the moment, we are hoping to run more online events like these to ensure across the piece.”Speaking about ABC Council’s shared history event SinnFein group leader, Councillor Liam Mackle said: “Many local people lost their lives in this conflict.“The Lord Mayor will pay
